docset.name: XSLT 1.0
docset.element:
This is an alias for the stylesheet element - almost never used.
&root-content;

A template defines a chunk of output. When using the match attribute, it can only be invoked by an apply-templates instruction (which can process multiple elements and their templates in a single operation), and is guaranteed to have the context of an element matching the pattern in the match attribute.
When using the name attribute, the template can be manually invoked by a call-template instruction, thus resembling a sub-routine in other languages.
The mode attribute facilitates multiple outputs for the same element, e.g. if an <article> needs a short version for the Table of Contents at the top of the output, and a longer version for the actual article content.
It's perfectly valid to have both a match and a name attribute on a template, if it makes sense. But you're required to use at least one of them.
&template-content;

description.p: This is used to generate a string value in the output by selecting something from the input document. The select attribute is an XPath expression - if it selects a node set, only the string value of the first node in the set will be output.
description.note: Though the disable-output-escaping attribute can be used to output text as HTML or XML, it is thus also possible to generate invalid XML - so be sure to know what the source contains before blindly transferring it to the output document.

description.p: Use this to generate a comment in the output.
description.note: This is necessary because a regular comment is in fact just a comment in the stylesheet, which is used to comment the code, and is in fact stripped by the XML parser before the XSLT processor gets the stylesheet.

element.name: processing-instruction

description.p: Generates a Processing Instruction in the output; usually used for adding some kind of machine-info to the file.
A processing instruction can be selected in an XPath expression using the processing-instruction() function.
description.note: Although the name attribute isn't required, no output will be generated if it's missing.

element.example: <!-- Generates something like this: <?doc-version v0.9.3.4 ?> --> <xsl:processing-instruction name="doc-version"> <xsl:value-of select="$version" /> </xsl:processing-instruction>

description.p: Collects the nodes specified by the select attribute and starts processing them using matching templates.
Using the mode attribute restricts the applied templates to only those with an identical mode attribute.
description.note: If no select attribute is present, it defaults to "*", i.e. the children of the current node.

element.name: apply-imports

description.p: This is used to allow the processor to process any imported templates that matches the context node

element.name: call-template

description.p: Explicitly call a named template (a template with a name attribute). The template will execute with the context at the point of this instruction.
If the template accepts arguments (parameters), use the with-param element to supply values to those.

element.example:
<!-- Simple --> <xsl:call-template name="headers" />
<!-- With argument --> <xsl:call-template name="fibonacci"> <xsl:with-param name="from" select="13" /> </xsl:call-template>

description.p: Similar to switch and if/elseif statements in other languages, this is used to choose between one or more outcomes. It's a bit verbose, and for simple A/B scenarios it's often possible to handle the logic in a single XPath statement instead.
Only the first when where the test returns true() will be executed (or, if no when-statements succeed, the contents of otherwise, if present).
Instructs the processor to remove all white-space nodes from specific elements in the source document before they're handled by XSLT.
description.note: You can use the value "*" to strip space from all elements.

description.p: Instructs the processor to preserve white-space nodes from specific elements in the source document before they're handled by XSLT.
description.note: The default behavior is to preserve white-space, so this element is provided so you can preserve specific elements' white-space, in case strip-space has been set to "all others" ("*").

docset.element:
Defines a value that can be used in many places, which should be easily changeable from e.g. the top of the file. Once defined, a parameter can be used by prefixing the name with a dollar-sign, e.g. <xsl:value-of select="$primary-color"> or <div class="{$selected-class}">.
A parameter is very similar to a variable, and none of them can be changed within the same transformation.
The difference between a parameter and a variable is that a parameter can be set from the XSLT Processor when invoking the transform.
&param-content;

description.p: Used to build a set of attributes for reuse on multiple output elements. Use the special xsl:use-attribute-sets attribute on any literal output element, to tell the processor to generate these attributes on the element.
Defines a named custom format for use with the number instruction and the format-number() function.
If present, this must be the first element inside a for-each or an apply-templates instruction.
Creates a named index of elements matching the expression in the match attribute. The value retrieved from the use attribute is stored as the index value.
description.note: To retrieve nodes from the index, use the XPath key() function.
The import statement(s) must appear before any other child node of the main stylesheet.

description.p: Used to output debugging/logging info to stdout during transformation. If the terminate attribute is set to yes, the transformation will terminate.
